elements.title: Criteria-Match Scan Pattern for Listing Evaluation
elements.problem: Walaa has exactly four evaluation criteria: price ($600-750/month), location (Astoria/Queens), roommate gender (female), and schedule compatibility (weekdays + every other weekend). When she taps a listing link from Bryant's text, she must determine whether this listing matches her criteria before anything else. Weinschenk Ch. 40 (attention is selective) means she will selectively attend to these four criteria and ignore everything else. But the listing page likely presents information in the marketplace's default hierarchy: photos first, then title, then price, then description, then amenities, then rules. Her four criteria are scattered across this hierarchy. Weinschenk Ch. 44 (sustained attention lasts about ten minutes) means if she cannot find her criteria quickly, she will abandon. The language barrier compounds this: even if the criteria are present, she may not recognize them in text form. The listing page's information architecture must reorganize around what this guest actually needs to know, not what the platform traditionally displays first.
elements.solution: Restructure listing page information hierarchy around a criteria-match pattern: at the top of every listing, before photos or description, show a compact match summary that answers the guest's four questions with visual indicators. (1) Budget match: show 'Est. $680/mo' with a green checkmark or red warning relative to her stated $600-750 range. (2) Location match: show 'Astoria, Queens' with proximity indicator. (3) Roommate info: show gender icon(s) for current occupants. (4) Schedule fit: show a week-bar visualization with her needed nights highlighted vs. available nights. Each criterion uses an icon-plus-value pair so comprehension does not depend on reading labels. Below this match summary, show photos and details in progressive disclosure. The match summary is the scan entry point; everything else is confirmation detail.

evidence.quote: It's between 600 to seven 50. This is my budget.
evidence.insight: Budget is a hard filter. If the listing page does not immediately show whether the price falls within her range, she cannot evaluate it. The information architecture must surface budget match as primary.

evidence.quote: I prefer to be alone, but if she needs sometimes... see me female roommate.
evidence.insight: Roommate gender is a stated filter criterion. It must appear in the scan zone alongside price and location, not buried in a house rules section.

evidence.quote: Attention is selective.
evidence.insight: Walaa will selectively attend to her four criteria. Information architecture that forces her to scan past irrelevant content (amenity lists, host bios) before reaching her criteria wastes her limited selective attention.

evidence.quote: People believe that things that are close together belong together.
evidence.insight: Grouping all four match criteria into a single proximity cluster at the top of the listing communicates that they are a unified evaluation tool, not scattered data points.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: criteria-match summary (budget, location, roommate, schedule) as a single visual cluster using icon-plus-value pairs. Secondary: listing photos and host summary. Tertiary: full description, amenities, house rules, and neighborhood details. The match summary answers 'Does this work for me?' The rest answers 'What is it like?'
elements.disclosure_pattern: Always visible: the four-criterion match summary at listing top, requiring zero scroll. First scroll: photos and host profile summary. Second scroll: full description, amenities, rules. Expandable: detailed pricing breakdown, cancellation terms, lease style explanation. The guest should never need to scroll to determine basic fit.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: The match summary must contain exactly 4 data points (budget, location, roommate, schedule), each expressed in 3 words or fewer plus one icon. No labels longer than one word. No paragraph text in the match zone. Total scan time for all four criteria: under 5 seconds.
scan_order: Budget match indicator with monthly estimate
Location name with distance or area
Roommate gender icon(s)
Schedule compatibility bar (nights available vs. needed)
exclude: Amenity lists in the match summary zone
Host bio text above the match summary
Nightly rate as primary price display
Review scores or ratings in the match summary (defer to below photos)
Platform branding or navigation competing with match criteria

elements.title: Intermediary-Contextualized Information Threading
elements.problem: Walaa's entire information pathway is mediated by Bryant. She did not discover Split Lease; she discovered Bryant on Craigslist. She will not search listings; Bryant will text her links. When she taps a link, her mental model is 'Bryant sent me this,' not 'I am browsing a marketplace.' Weinschenk Ch. 31 (people create mental models) establishes that Walaa has constructed a model where information flows through a trusted human, not through a platform interface. Ch. 32 (people interact with conceptual models) means the platform's self-service conceptual model directly conflicts with her human-mediated mental model. When information arrives without Bryant's context -- a generic listing page, an anonymous form, a platform notification -- Walaa loses the trust thread that motivated her to engage. The information architecture problem is not about what content to show, but about whose voice the content appears to come from.
elements.solution: Thread the intermediary's context through every information touchpoint in the pre-lease journey. (1) When Bryant sends a listing link, the URL should carry a referral parameter that personalizes the landing page: 'Bryant recommended this for you' as a persistent context bar at the top of the listing. (2) On the listing page, show which of Walaa's criteria Bryant matched: 'Matches your budget ($680/mo is within your $600-750 range).' This requires Bryant to have logged her criteria during intake, which he already captured in the call. (3) At proposal creation, frame the action as communication with Bryant, not platform interaction: 'Tell Bryant you're interested' rather than 'Create Proposal.' (4) In all platform-generated messages (confirmations, status updates), include Bryant's name: 'Bryant is working on connecting you with this host.' Weinschenk Ch. 84 (people want what is familiar when scared) means Bryant's name is the familiar element that prevents retreat when the platform feels foreign.

evidence.quote: I can share some listings with you just over text, if that works and you can let me know if any of them interests you.
evidence.insight: The information channel is text-from-Bryant, not platform-search. Every platform page Walaa reaches was preceded by a text from Bryant. The page must acknowledge this origin to maintain trust continuity.

evidence.quote: Hello is this, um, is it... I'm talking to you or am I talking to, uh, her, her friend.
evidence.insight: Walaa is confused about who she is interacting with even in a phone call. On a platform page with no human context, this confusion will be worse. The intermediary's name must be visibly threaded through every touchpoint.

evidence.quote: People create mental models.
evidence.insight: Walaa's mental model is 'Bryant helps me find a room.' Information architecture that does not include Bryant breaks the model. Every screen must answer the implicit question: 'Is this still from Bryant?'

evidence.quote: People use look and feel as their first indicator of trust.
evidence.insight: Walaa's trust was established through Bryant's voice. The platform's look and feel must extend this trust by visually referencing Bryant's involvement, not replacing it with generic platform branding.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: intermediary context bar ('Bryant recommended this' or 'Bryant is helping you'). Secondary: matched criteria with intermediary attribution ('Matches the budget you told Bryant'). Tertiary: platform-native content (listing details, forms, actions). The intermediary's name appears at or above every transition where the guest moves from text message to platform interface.
elements.disclosure_pattern: The intermediary context bar is always visible at the top of any page reached via an agent-shared link. It persists across page transitions (listing to proposal to confirmation). It collapses into a small badge after the guest's third platform visit, reflecting the gradual mental model transition from mediated to self-service. It never fully disappears during the pre-lease journey.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: The intermediary context bar must be one line of text maximum, using the agent's first name and a brief action phrase. No paragraphs. No explanation of who the agent is or how the platform works. The context bar adds trust, not information load.
scan_order: Intermediary context bar at page top
Matched criteria with intermediary attribution
Listing or form content
Action button framed as communication with intermediary
exclude: Generic platform welcome messages on agent-referred pages
Account creation prompts before the guest has evaluated a listing
Platform feature tours or onboarding modals that interrupt the agent's curated flow
Any screen that requires the guest to understand the platform's self-service model before they have completed at least one agent-mediated transaction

elements.title: Monthly-Budget-Frame Price Architecture Across All Touchpoints
elements.problem: Walaa states her budget as '$600 to seven 50' -- a monthly frame. The platform uses nightly rates and 4-week rent as its pricing architecture. This creates a frame mismatch at every price touchpoint. Weinschenk Ch. 28 (some types of mental processing are more challenging than others) establishes that translating between pricing frames requires a type of mental processing that is inherently more difficult than comparing like-for-like numbers. For Walaa, the translation is even harder because her alternating schedule means the monthly cost varies between 4-night weeks (~$100/week) and 7-night weeks (~$175/week), producing irregular monthly totals. She cannot perform this computation. If the first number she sees is '$25/night,' her unconscious decision system (Ch. 90) will process it as 'I don't know if this fits my budget' and generate confusion rather than evaluation. The pricing architecture must present numbers in her frame, not the platform's frame.
elements.solution: Establish a guest-budget-frame pricing architecture that persists across all four price-displaying phases. (1) During listing evaluation: show 'Est. monthly cost: $XXX' as the primary price, computed from the guest's known schedule pattern (if captured during intake) or a default full-month estimate. Nightly rate appears as secondary text below. (2) During proposal creation: show a live-updating monthly total as the guest selects or confirms dates: 'This month: $680 (17 nights x $40).' The monthly total is visually dominant; the per-night breakdown is explanatory subtext. (3) During negotiation: when the host counters with a different nightly rate, show the impact in monthly terms: 'Host suggested $45/night. For your schedule, that is approximately $760/month.' Place this next to the guest's stated budget range for instant comparison. (4) At acceptance: the summary leads with 'Monthly Cost: $XXX' and 'First Payment: $XXX.' Nightly rate is a footnote. Weinschenk Ch. 90 (unconscious decisions) means the first number Walaa sees is the number her gut evaluates -- make it the monthly number she can compare to her budget.

evidence.quote: It's between 600 to seven 50. This is my budget.
evidence.insight: The budget frame is monthly. Period. Any pricing display that requires Walaa to convert from nightly to monthly is a cognitive tax that the platform imposes on the guest.

evidence.quote: I want to ask to both, if we make it like this, or if we make it their monthly, how long both options is available for me.
evidence.insight: Walaa is already confused about pricing formats during a human conversation. On a platform screen with no human to clarify, the confusion will be paralyzing.

evidence.quote: Some types of mental processing are more challenging than others.
evidence.insight: Frame translation (nightly to monthly, adjusted for irregular schedule) is a high-difficulty computation. The information architecture must perform this computation for the guest, not require her to do it.

evidence.quote: People make most decisions unconsciously.
evidence.insight: The first price number Walaa encounters triggers an unconscious accept/reject evaluation. That number must be in her budget frame (monthly) or the unconscious evaluation will produce confusion, not a decision.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: monthly cost estimate (large, dark, visually dominant). Secondary: per-night rate as explanatory context (smaller, lighter). Tertiary: fee breakdowns, deposit information, and payment schedule (expandable, behind tap). Budget comparison ('Within your $600-750 range') appears as a contextual badge adjacent to the monthly cost whenever the guest's budget is known.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Monthly cost is always visible without scrolling at every price touchpoint. Per-night rate is visible but visually subordinate. Fee breakdown (service fee, cleaning fee, deposit) is behind an expandable section labeled 'See breakdown.' Payment schedule (first payment, recurring dates) is on the acceptance screen only, below the monthly summary.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 2 numbers visible in the primary price zone: monthly estimate and nightly rate. No additional fee line items in the primary zone. The guest should compare one number (monthly estimate) against one number (her budget) and reach a conclusion in under 3 seconds.
scan_order: Monthly cost estimate with budget-match indicator
Nightly rate as secondary explanatory line
Budget comparison badge (within range / over budget)
Expandable fee breakdown link
exclude: Nightly rate as the primary or largest number on any screen
Multiple fee line items visible without expansion
Total-stay-cost as primary display for multi-month stays (too large a number, triggers sticker shock)
Currency conversion or tax estimates in the primary price zone

elements.title: Uncertainty-Tolerant Commitment Disclosure Pattern
elements.problem: Walaa cannot commit to a lease duration: 'I don't know because no, I I'm not fixing yet in this worker, so I don't know how to be' (5:11-5:22). This is not reluctance to commit -- it is genuine inability to predict her own future. Weinschenk Ch. 30 (the more uncertain people are, the more they defend their ideas) predicts that if the proposal form forces a duration choice, Walaa will defensively refuse rather than guess. Ch. 93 (people think choice equals control) means offering a flexible option gives perceived control. But the information architecture problem goes deeper: every commitment-requiring screen (proposal creation, acceptance, lease terms) must communicate that flexibility is built in, not that rigidity is the default with flexibility as an exception. If the flexible option is buried below fixed durations or requires extra clicks to discover, the page's information hierarchy communicates that fixed commitment is normal and flexibility is unusual. For uncertain guests, this framing causes abandonment because they feel the platform is not designed for them.
elements.solution: Design commitment screens with uncertainty as the default information state, not the exception. (1) At proposal creation, present duration options in this order: 'Flexible (month-to-month, 2 weeks notice)' first, then fixed durations (1 month, 2 months, 3 months) below. The flexible option is pre-selected. Weinschenk Ch. 57 (people are inherently lazy) means the pre-selected option is the one most guests will accept. (2) At acceptance, frame the commitment as reversible: lead with 'Your stay renews monthly' as the headline, not 'Lease Duration: Flexible.' The word 'renews' communicates ongoing control; the word 'lease' communicates lock-in. (3) During active_lease, show 'Currently on month 3. Renews automatically. Change or end anytime with 2 weeks notice.' This persistent reassurance prevents the uncertainty from resurfacing as anxiety each month. (4) The Date Change Tool link should appear on every active_lease screen, communicating that schedule modification is a first-class platform capability, not a support request.

evidence.quote: I don't know. I don't know because no, I I'm not fixing yet in this worker, so I don't know how to be.
evidence.insight: Duration uncertainty is not a soft preference -- it is a hard constraint. Any information architecture that treats duration as a required input blocks this guest entirely.

evidence.quote: People think choice equals control.
evidence.insight: The flexible option must be positioned as the first and most prominent choice, not buried as an alternative. Its visual prominence communicates that the platform was designed for guests who need flexibility.

evidence.quote: The more uncertain people are, the more they defend their ideas.
evidence.insight: Forcing Walaa to pick a duration triggers defensiveness, not commitment. The information architecture must make flexibility feel like the platform's recommendation, not the guest's special request.

evidence.quote: People overestimate reactions to future events.
evidence.insight: Walaa fears commitment more than the actual commitment warrants. Framing acceptance as 'renews monthly' rather than '3-month lease' reduces the perceived magnitude of the commitment.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: flexibility reassurance ('Renews monthly' or 'Flexible, month-to-month'). Secondary: current status ('Month 3 of your stay'). Tertiary: modification options ('Change dates' or 'End stay'). The hierarchy communicates ongoing control at every commitment screen, with the flexibility message always at or near the top.
elements.disclosure_pattern: The flexibility framing is always visible on commitment screens (proposal duration selector, acceptance summary, active lease dashboard). Fixed-duration options are available but visually subordinate. Lease terms and cancellation details are expandable, not primary. The Date Change Tool link is persistent on every active_lease screen, not hidden behind a menu.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Duration selection screen: maximum 4 options (Flexible + 3 fixed). Flexible is pre-selected, requiring zero input to proceed. No duration justification required. No penalty language ('Higher rate for flexible') visible in the primary zone. Acceptance screen: one sentence framing the commitment, one sentence explaining how to change it.
scan_order: Flexibility reassurance headline
Pre-selected flexible option
Fixed-duration alternatives (if guest wants to lock in)
Modification/cancellation link
exclude: Fixed duration as the default selection
Penalty pricing for flexibility displayed alongside the option (defer to detail screen)
Legal lease language on the selection screen
Any phrasing that frames flexibility as an exception or accommodation rather than the standard offering

elements.title: Stays Manager Weekly Scan Architecture for Habit Formation
elements.problem: The active_lease phase repeats for 13+ weeks. Each week, Walaa opens the Stays Manager to check her status, confirm arrival, and eventually submit micro-reviews. Weinschenk Ch. 42 (well-practiced skills don't require conscious attention) defines the target: by week 5, the weekly interaction should be automatic. But automaticity requires that the information architecture is identical every visit. Ch. 6 (people scan screens based on past experience and expectations) means Walaa builds a spatial map of where information lives -- if that map changes, she must re-learn. Her alternating schedule (4-night weeks vs. 7-night weeks) adds complexity: the information displayed must change between week types, but the information structure must not. The architecture must accommodate variable content within a fixed frame. Additionally, her language barrier means the scan pattern must rely on spatial position and visual indicators, not on reading text labels each time.
elements.solution: Design the Stays Manager as a fixed three-zone scan architecture that never changes layout but adapts content: (1) Zone 1 (top, always visible): 'This Week' status card -- shows week type (short/full) via color-coded badge, arrival/departure dates, and a single action button (confirm arrival, rate stay, or 'all done'). This zone answers 'What do I need to know and do right now?' (2) Zone 2 (middle): Progress tracker -- a horizontal bar or dot sequence showing completed stays, current week highlighted, remaining weeks ahead. Weinschenk Ch. 50 (more motivated as closer to goal) means this tracker sustains engagement as the lease progresses. (3) Zone 3 (bottom, scrollable): History feed -- past weeks with their micro-review ratings (emoji faces), payment confirmations, and any host messages. This zone answers 'What happened before?' and provides the recognition-based interface (Ch. 22) for review data. The three zones occupy fixed screen positions every week. Zone 1 content changes (different dates, different action), but Zone 1 is always at the top, always one card, always one button.

evidence.quote: Monday to Friday, each week and then every other weekend... I traveled to another state every other weekend.
evidence.insight: The alternating schedule means the Stays Manager must display different week content (4 nights vs. 7 nights) without changing the scan architecture. A color-coded badge (e.g., blue for short week, purple for full week) lets Walaa recognize her week type without reading.

evidence.quote: Well-practiced skills don't require conscious attention.
evidence.insight: Automaticity requires consistency. If the Stays Manager layout changes -- even once -- during the lease, Walaa's developing habit is disrupted. The three-zone architecture must be locked for the duration of the lease.

evidence.quote: People scan screens based on past experience and expectations.
evidence.insight: By week 3, Walaa's eyes go directly to Zone 1 for this week's status, then Zone 2 for progress. This spatial habit is the foundation of sub-30-second weekly interactions.

evidence.quote: People are more motivated as they get closer to a goal.
evidence.insight: The progress tracker in Zone 2 leverages goal-gradient motivation. As Walaa sees 10 of 13 stays completed, her motivation to complete the remaining interactions increases, sustaining engagement through the final weeks.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Zone 1 (top): this week's status and action -- visually dominant, one card, one button. Zone 2 (middle): progress tracker -- medium visual weight, horizontal orientation, always visible. Zone 3 (bottom, scrollable): history feed -- lighter visual weight, recognition-based, grows over time. The hierarchy is fixed. Content changes; structure does not.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Zone 1 shows the current action without expansion. Zone 2 shows the full progress bar without expansion. Zone 3 shows the most recent 3 past weeks; older weeks load on scroll. Detailed payment breakdowns, host messages, and review history are behind taps on individual history items. Nothing in Zones 1 or 2 ever requires expansion or drilling down.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Zone 1: maximum 4 data points (week type badge, dates, nights count, one action button). Zone 2: a single visual element (progress bar or dot sequence) with no text labels beyond the current position indicator. Zone 3: each history item is one line (week number, emoji rating, payment status). Total first-screen content: under 10 distinct visual elements.
scan_order: Zone 1: week type badge (color recognition, not text)
Zone 1: action button (what do I need to do?)
Zone 2: progress position (where am I in my stay?)
Zone 3: most recent history item (what happened last week?)
exclude: Navigation menus or tabs within the Stays Manager (it is one scrollable page)
Feature announcements or platform tips in any zone
Multiple action buttons in Zone 1 (one action per visit)
Layout changes between week types (only content and badge color change)

elements.title: Icon-Anchored House Manual for Recognition-Based Wayfinding
elements.problem: Walaa arrives at her new living space needing to find practical information: Wi-Fi password, door code, trash schedule, shared space rules, emergency contacts. The House Manual is her reference document. Weinschenk Ch. 22 (it's easier to recognize information than recall it) means the manual must be a recognition tool -- Walaa should see an icon and know what category it represents, not remember where information was stored. Ch. 23 (memory takes a lot of mental resources) means she cannot be expected to memorize information from the manual; she must be able to retrieve it instantly every time. Her language barrier makes a text-heavy manual nearly useless: she may read the words 'Garbage Collection Schedule' but not know which day to put the bins out or where the bins are. Weinschenk Ch. 7 (people see cues that tell them what to do with an object / affordances) means the manual's categories must have clear visual affordances that communicate 'tap here for Wi-Fi' without requiring text comprehension.
elements.solution: Structure the House Manual as an icon-grid landing page with maximum 6 category tiles, each using a universally recognizable icon and a one-word label. (1) Wi-Fi tile: Wi-Fi icon + password displayed directly on the tile (no tap required for the most-needed info). (2) Keys/Access tile: key icon, tapping shows door code, lockbox location with photo, and key instructions. (3) Trash tile: bin icon, tapping shows pickup days with a simple Mon/Tue/Wed visual calendar and a photo of the actual bins. (4) Rules tile: house icon, tapping shows the top 3 rules as icon-plus-short-phrase pairs (quiet hours clock icon + '10pm-8am', no smoking icon, guest policy icon). (5) Emergency tile: red cross icon, tapping shows host phone number with one-tap call button, plus 911 reminder. (6) Neighborhood tile: map pin icon, tapping shows the 3 nearest essentials (grocery, pharmacy, transit) with walking-time estimates. Weinschenk Ch. 3 (pattern recognition) means each tile uses a distinct icon shape that Walaa can identify without reading. The grid layout remains constant throughout her lease so she builds spatial memory of where each category lives.

evidence.quote: Um, no, you weren't asked how you should assist me or What was that?
evidence.insight: Walaa's difficulty parsing conversational English predicts that text-heavy documents will be incomprehensible. The House Manual must communicate through icons and photos, not paragraphs.

evidence.quote: It's easier to recognize information than recall it.
evidence.insight: The icon-grid pattern lets Walaa recognize the category she needs (Wi-Fi icon = internet password) rather than recall where the information was in a text document. Recognition is faster and language-independent.

evidence.quote: People see cues that tell them what to do with an object.
evidence.insight: Each tile in the icon grid is a visual affordance: the Wi-Fi icon cues 'tap here for internet,' the key icon cues 'tap here for access.' These affordances communicate function without requiring text comprehension.

evidence.quote: People process information better in bite-sized chunks.
evidence.insight: Six tiles with one-word labels is the maximum chunk size. Each tile opens to a single-screen detail view with a photo and 3 bullet points maximum. No category contains more information than can be absorbed in 10 seconds.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: 6-tile icon grid as the House Manual landing page, each tile with a universal icon and one-word label. Secondary: within each tile, one photo of the actual item/location plus 1-3 short instructions. Tertiary: additional details (full house rules document, neighborhood guide, host bio) accessible but never competing with the icon grid for attention.
elements.disclosure_pattern: The icon grid is the always-visible landing page. Tapping a tile opens a single-screen detail view with photo + short instructions. No multi-level navigation within the manual. Back button returns to the grid. Wi-Fi password is displayed directly on the tile without tapping (the single exception to the tap-to-reveal pattern, because it is the most frequently needed item).
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Landing page: exactly 6 tiles, no more. Each tile: 1 icon + 1 word. Detail view: 1 photo + maximum 3 bullet points of text. No scrolling within detail views. No links to external resources from within the manual. Total categories must map to the 6-item recognition limit for unfamiliar interfaces.
scan_order: Icon grid overview (which category do I need?)
Wi-Fi password visible on tile surface
Tap target tile for detail
Photo of actual item/location in detail view
1-3 instruction bullets
exclude: Text-heavy welcome letters on the manual landing page
Host bios or personal messages competing with practical information
More than 6 categories on the landing page
Links to external websites, PDFs, or additional documents within the manual
Any information requiring the guest to scroll before finding the icon grid
